user_message:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the: 1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter. 2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body. 3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body. 4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of init_response_body_data: ```c static int init_response_body_data (void) { if (0 != body_dyn_size) { body_dyn = (char *) malloc (body_dyn_size); if (NULL == body_dyn) { fprintf (stderr, "Failed to allocate memory.\n"); return 0; } if (tool_params.medium) { /* Fill the body with HTML-like content */ size_t pos; size_t filler_pos; static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n"; static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n"; static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n"; pos = 0; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_header, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header)); pos += MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header); for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } pos += filler_pos; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); } else { /* Fill the body with binary-like content */ size_t pos; for (pos = 0; pos < body_dyn_size; ++pos) { body_dyn[pos] = (char) (unsigned char) (255U - pos % 256U); } } } return ! 0; } ``` Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function init_response_body_data: static size_t body_dyn_size ... static char *body_dyn = NULL ... #define MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(macro) (sizeof(macro)/sizeof(char)-1) ... static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n" ... static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n" ... static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n" Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.2 or not.
scenario: No violation. The for loop initializes a single loop counter (filler_pos = 0), the loop-condition uses that counter and constant expressions (body_dyn_size and compile-time lengths obtained via sizeof) which are not modified in the loop body, and the third clause increments only the loop counter (++filler_pos). The loop body does not modify filler_pos (only writes into body_dyn and reads body_filler/pos), and there are no function calls in the loop that could produce persistent side effects on the objects used in the condition. Therefore Rule 14.2 is not violated.
